repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: needs the usual headers, note about "gO", etc
was this intentionally removed? the purpose is to positively confirm that something is actually being tested. otherwise it's possible that `eq(0, err_count)` (below) could be a false negative.

Yes, intentional. It seems useless.

> the purpose is to positively confirm that something is actually being tested.

Don't know what you mean. We're asserting that the length of the table is the length of the table.
We can rewrite this as `eq(vim.tbl_count(rv.helpfiles), #rv.helpfiles)` if you prefer that more?

That's a _different_ table than the one on line 1441 , though (output, not input). The check is basically asserting that every input file (the list in line 1441, whose -- known -- length `3` is the first argument) indeed got processed (is part of the output).

In that case we should be comparing the computed length of the input table as to not need to manually update this value every time we remove or add an element rather than hardcode it. There is no way to know the intention of what `3` is supposed to mean without prior knowledge.
That makes sense, yes, and would be a useful change.

comment_regular_data.body:
I think I'd prefer this to be a coordinated "Problem: lua.txt is too large" split-up into more dedicated files (**iff** we decide that this is in fact a problem, which I don't believe we have?) I don't think `vim.health` is any larger or more different than, say, `vim.iter` or `vim.fs`.

My biggest gripe with `lua.txt` is the inconsistent headings (e.g., the `Ringbuf` module being part of `vim.inspector`). Try `gO` -- making that look sane would be a better first step.

> iff we decide that this is in fact a problem, which I don't believe we have?

I interpreted @justinmk's response in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/28915#issuecomment-2126641258 to indicate that he was not satisfied with merging the health docs to lua.txt which is why I extracted it. I'm not sure what the problem we're solving here either but I don't care about this enough to argue about it.

That is not my interpretation (but he will say what he meant himself); it looked to me like only a general comment that it's not _necessary_ for Lua modules to live in `lua.txt` (but that it's a good default, so your PR is good).

> That is not my interpretation (but he will say what he meant himself); it looked to me like only a general comment that it's not _necessary_ for Lua modules to live in `lua.txt` (but that it's a good default, so your PR is good).

For note keeping and reference: spoke to justin in private and I did indeed interpret him correctly and that he prefers health.txt being a separate file.

I will try documenting his reasoning in a way that makes sense in this PR.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: docs: extract health to its own file
